[[Ashutosh Saxena]] | nationality = American | children = 2 }} {{Infobox Chinese |t = 吳恩達 |s = 吴恩达 |p = Wú Ēndá |j = ng4 jan1 daat6 }} '''Andrew Yan-Tak Ng''' ({{zh|t=吳恩達}}; born 1976) is a British-born American [[computer scientist]] and [[Internet Entrepreneur|technology entrepreneur]] focusing on [[machine learning]] and [[Artificial intelligence|AI]]. Ng was a co-founder and head of [[Google Brain]] and was the former Chief Scientist at [[Baidu]], building the company's Artificial Intelligence Group into a team of several thousand people.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/22/business/baidu-artificial-intelligence-andrew-ng.html|title=A.I. Expert at Baidu, Andrew Ng, Resigns From Chinese Search Giant |last=Mozur|first=Paul|date=March 22, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=April 17, 2019|issn=0362-4331}} Ng is an [[adjunct professor]] at [[Stanford University]] (formerly associate professor and Director of its [[Stanford AI Lab]] or SAIL). Ng has also made substantial contributions to the field of [[online education]] as the co-founder of both [[Coursera]] and [https://www.deeplearning.ai/ deeplearning.ai].{{cite web|url=https://www.coursera.org/instructor/andrewng|title=Andrew Ng — Stanford University {{!}} Coursera|website=Coursera|access-date=August 29, 2017}} He has spearheaded many efforts to "democratize deep learning" teaching over 2.5 million students through his online courses.{{Citation|title=Andrew Ng at Amazon re:MARS 2019|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j2nGxw8sKYU |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/j2nGxw8sKYU |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|language=en|access-date=2019-11-20}}{{cbignore}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/4032920/baidus-head-of-artificial-intelligence-is-stepping-down|title=Baidu's head of artificial intelligence is stepping down|last=Terdiman|first=Daniel|date=March 22, 2017|website=Fast Company|access-date=April 17, 2019}} He is one of the world's most famous and influential computer scientists being named one of ''Time'' magazine's [[Time 100|100 Most Influential People]] in 2012, and ''[[Fast Company]]''{{'s}} Most Creative People in 2014. In 2018, he launched and currently heads the AI Fund, initially a $175-million investment fund for backing artificial intelligence startups. He has founded Landing AI, which provides AI-powered [[SaaS]] products.{{cite web|url=https://landing.ai/|title=Home|website=Landing AI|access-date=April 17, 2019}} == Biography == Ng was born in the [[United Kingdom]] in 1976. His parents Ronald P. Ng and [[Tisa Ho]]{{cite news |last1=Ng |first1=Terry |title=After His Son Co-Founded Coursera, He Became Its Earliest Student and Completed 146 Courses |url=https://www.ricemedia.co/culture-people-after-son-cofounded-coursera-became-earliest-student-completed-146-courses/ |publisher=Rice Media |date=September 26, 2020}}{{cite news |title=Healer, teacher |url=https://www.asiaone.com/health/healer-teacher |access-date=25 February 2022 |publisher=The Straits Times}}{{cite journal |last1=Miquiabas |first1=Bong |title=A.I. and the New Era of Business |journal=The Peak Magazine Hong Kong |date=July 2015 |pages=40–45 |url=https://www.cs.cityu.edu.hk/~hwchun/AIProjects/pdf/The%20Peak%20-%20AI%20-%20small.pdf}} are both immigrants from [[Hong Kong]]. He has at least one brother. Growing up, he spent time in Hong Kong and [[Singapore]] and later graduated from [[Raffles Institution]] in Singapore in 1992. In 1997, he earned his undergraduate degree with a triple major in [[computer science]], [[statistics]], and [[economics]] from [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], graduating at the top of his class. Between 1996 and 1998 he also conducted research on [[reinforcement learning]], [[model selection]], and [[feature selection]] at the [[Bell Labs|AT&T Bell Labs]]. In 1998 Ng earned his [[master's degree]] from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. At MIT he built the first publicly available, automatically indexed web-search engine for research papers on the web (it was a precursor to [[CiteSeerX|CiteSeer]]/[[ResearchIndex]], but specialized in machine learning). In 2002, he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], under the supervision of [[Michael I. Jordan]]. His thesis is titled "Shaping and policy search in [[reinforcement learning]]" and is well cited to this day.{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/curriculum-vitae.pdf|title=Cirriculum Vitae—Andrew Y. Ng|last=Ng|first=Andrew}}{{cite web|url=http://rail.eecs.berkeley.edu/deeprlcourse-fa17/docs/ng-thesis.pdf|title=Shaping and policy search in Reinforcement Learning|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=2003}} He started working as an assistant professor at [[Stanford University]] in 2002, and as an associate professor at 2009.{{Cite web|last=Ng|first=Andrew Y.|date=May 20, 2015|title=Curriculum Vitæ—Andrew Y. Ng|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/curriculum-vitae.pdf|access-date=October 9, 2020|website=Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory}} He currently lives in [[Los Altos Hills]], [[California]]. In 2014, he married [[Carol E. Reiley]].{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/13/andrew-ng_n_7267682.html|title=Inside The Mind That Built Google Brain: On Life, Creativity, And Failure|date=May 13, 2015|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=December 19, 2015}} They have two children: a daughter born in 2019{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AndrewYNg/status/1098331008544399360|title=Announcing Nova Ng, our first daughter. Plus, some thoughts on the AI-powered world she will grow up in...|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=February 20, 2019|website=@AndrewYNg|access-date=March 7, 2019}} and a son born in 2021.{{cite web|url=https://read.deeplearning.ai/the-batch/issue-106/|title= The Batch – Issue 106 |first=Andrew |last=Ng |date= 25 August 2021 |publisher= |via= DeepLearning.ai}} The ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'' named Ng and Reiley an "AI power couple". == Career == === Academia and teaching === Ng is a [[professor]] at Stanford University Department of Computer Science and Department of [[Electrical engineering|Electrical Engineering]]. He served as the director of the [[Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory|Stanford Artificial Intelligence Lab (SAIL)]], where he taught students and undertook research related to [[data mining]], [[big data]], and machine learning. His machine learning course CS229 at Stanford is the most popular course offered on campus with over 1000 students enrolling some years.{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2013/12/29/why-is-machine-learning-cs-229-the-most-popular-course-at-stanford/ | work=Forbes | year=2013 | title=Why Is Machine Learning (CS 229) The Most Popular Course At Stanford?}}{{cite web|url=http://cs229.stanford.edu/|title=CS229: Machine Learning|website=cs229.stanford.edu|access-date=April 17, 2019}} As of 2020, three of most popular courses on Coursera are Ng's: Machine Learning (#1), AI for Everyone, (#5), Neural Networks and Deep Learning (#6).{{Cite web|last=Mundial|first=Foro Económico|date=2020-10-27|title=Coursera's Most Popular Online Courses|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/358518|access-date=2020-12-26|website=Entrepreneur|language=en}} In 2008 his group at Stanford was one of the first in the US to start advocating the use of [[Graphics processing unit|GPUs]] in deep learning. The rationale was that an efficient computation infrastructure could speed up [[statistical model]] training by orders of magnitude, ameliorating some of the scaling issues associated with big data. At the time it was a controversial and risky decision, but since then and following Ng's lead, GPUs have become a cornerstone in the field.{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-does-Andrew-Ng-think-about-Deep-Learning|title=What does Andrew Ng think about Deep Learning? – Quora|website=quora.com|access-date=April 17, 2019}} Since 2017 Ng has been advocating the shift to [[high performance computing]] (HPC) for scaling up deep learning and accelerating progress in the field. In 2012, along with Stanford computer scientist [[Daphne Koller]] he co-founded and was CEO of [[Coursera]], a website that offers free online courses to everyone.{{failed reference|date=May 2020}} It took off with over 100,000 students registered for Ng's popular CS229A course.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/16/opinion/friedman-come-the-revolution.html|title=Opinion {{!}} Come the Revolution |last=Friedman|first=Thomas L.|date=May 15, 2012|work=The New York Times|access-date=February 19, 2018|issn=0362-4331}} Today, several million people have enrolled in Coursera courses, making the site one of the leading [[Massive open online course|MOOCs]] in the world. === Industry === From 2011 to 2012, he worked at [[Google]], where he founded and directed the [[Google Brain]] Deep Learning Project with [[Jeff Dean (computer scientist)|Jeff Dean]], Greg Corrado, and Rajat Monga. In 2014, he joined [[Baidu]] as chief scientist, and carried out research related to big data and AI.{{cite web|url=https://www.recode.net/2014/5/16/11626966/baidu-hires-coursera-founder-andrew-ng-to-start-massive-research-lab|title=Baidu Hires Coursera Founder Andrew Ng to Start Massive Research Lab|last=Gannes|first=Liz|date=May 16, 2014|website=Recode|access-date=August 29, 2017}} There he set up several research teams for things like [[Facial recognition system|facial recognition]] and Melody, an AI [[chatbot]] for [[Health care|healthcare]]. In March 2017, he announced his resignation from Baidu.{{cite web|title=Opening a new chapter of my work in AI |url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/opening-a-new-chapter-of-my-work-in-ai-c6a4d1595d7b| year=2017 | access-date=May 16, 2014}} He soon afterwards launched Deeplearning.ai, an online series of deep learning courses.{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/deeplearning-ai-announcing-new-deep-learning-courses-on-coursera-43af0a368116|title=deeplearning.ai: Announcing new Deep Learning courses on Coursera|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=August 8, 2017|website=Medium|access-date=February 19, 2018}} Then Ng launched Landing AI, which provides AI-powered [[SaaS]] products. In January 2018, Ng unveiled the AI Fund, raising $175 million to invest in new [[Startup company|startups]].{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/01/30/andrew-ng-unveils-the-ai-fund-with-175-million-to-back-new-startups/|title=Andrew Ng unveils the AI Fund, with $175 million to back new startups {{!}} VentureBeat|website=venturebeat.com|access-date=February 19, 2018|date=January 30, 2018}} In November 2021, Landing AI secured a $57 million round of series A funding led by McRock Capital, to help manufacturers adopt computer vision.{{Cite web|date=2021-11-08|title=MLOps platform Landing AI raises $57M to help manufacturers adopt computer vision|url=https://venturebeat.com/2021/11/08/mlops-platform-landing-ai-raises-57m-to-help-manufacturers-adopt-computer-vision/|access-date=2021-11-09|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US}} == Research == Ng researches primarily in [[machine learning]], [[deep learning]], [[machine perception]], [[computer vision]], and [[natural language processing]]; and is one of the world's most famous and influential computer scientists.{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/andrew-ng-ai-artificial-intelligence-playbook-2018-12|title=One of the world's most famous computer scientists reveals his 'playbook' for bringing AI to every business|work=Business Insider|year=2018}} He's frequently won best paper awards at academic conferences and has had a huge impact on the field of AI, computer vision, and robotics.{{Cite web|title=Andrew Ng – Publications|url=http://www.robotics.stanford.edu/~ang/papers.php|access-date=2020-12-26|website=www.robotics.stanford.edu}}{{Cite web|title=publications|url=http://ai.stanford.edu/~pabbeel/publications.html|access-date=2020-12-26|website=ai.stanford.edu}} During graduate school, together with [[David M. Blei]] and [[Michael I. Jordan]], Ng coauthored the influential paper that introduced [[latent Dirichlet allocation]] (LDA) for his thesis on reinforcement learning for drones.David M. Blei, Andrew Y. Ng, Michael I. Jordan. Latent Dirichlet allocation. The Journal of Machine Learning Research, Volume 3, January 3, 2003, which is one of the two papers that independently discovered [[Latent Dirichlet allocation]] His early work includes the Stanford Autonomous Helicopter project, which developed one of the most capable autonomous helicopters in the world.{{cite news| url=http://chronicle.com/article/From-Self-Flying-Helicopters/134666/| work=Chronicle of Higher Education | year=2012 | title=From Self-Flying Helicopters to Classrooms of the Future}}{{cite web |url=http://heli.stanford.edu |title=Stanford Autonomous Helicopter Project}} He was the leading scientist and principal investigator on the STAIR (STanford Artificial Intelligence Robot) project,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/18/technology/18brain.html | newspaper=The New York Times | author=John Markoff | title= Brainy Robots Start Stepping Into Daily Life | date=July 18, 2006}} which resulted in [[ROS (Robot Operating System)|ROS]], a widely used [[open source software|open-source]] [[robotics]] software platform. His vision to build an AI robot and put a robot in every home inspired Scott Hassan to back him and create [[Willow Garage]].{{Cite book|last=Markoff|first=John|title=Machines of Loving Grace: The Quest for Common Ground between humans and robots|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|year=2015|isbn=978-0-06-226668-2|location=New York|pages=}} He is also one of the founding team members for the Stanford WordNet project, which uses machine learning to expand the [[Princeton University|Princeton]] [[WordNet]] database created by [[Christiane Fellbaum]].{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~rion/swn/|title=The Stanford Wordnet Project|website=ai.stanford.edu|access-date=April 17, 2019}} In 2011, Ng founded the [[Google Brain]] project at [[Google]], which developed large-scale artificial [[neural network]]s using Google's distributed computer infrastructure.{{cite news |title= Google's Lab of Wildest Dreams |newspaper = The New York Times |author = Claire Miller and Nick Bilton |date = November 3, 2011 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/14/technology/at-google-x-a-top-secret-lab-dreaming-up-the-future.html }} Among its notable results was a neural network trained using [[deep learning]] algorithms on 16,000 [[CPU core]]s, which learned to recognize cats after watching only [[YouTube]] videos, and without ever having been told what a "cat" is.{{cite news |title= How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000 |newspaper = The New York Times |author=John Markoff |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/26/technology/in-a-big-network-of-computers-evidence-of-machine-learning.html |date=June 25, 2012 }}{{cite arXiv |title= Building High-level Features Using Large Scale Unsupervised Learning |last1=Ng |first1=Andrew |last2=Dean |first2=Jeff |eprint=1112.6209|year=2012 |class=cs.LG }} The project's technology is also currently used in the [[Android (operating system)|Android Operating System]]'s speech recognition system.{{cite web|url=http://googleresearch.blogspot.com/2012/08/speech-recognition-and-deep-learning.html|title=Speech Recognition and Deep Learning|work=Google Research Blog|date=August 6, 2012|access-date=January 29, 2013}} == Online education: MOOCs == {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | audio1 = [http://degreeoffreedom.org/interview-with-coursera-co-founder-andrew-ng/ Interview with Coursera Co-Founder Andrew Ng], Degree of Freedom{{cite web | title =Interview with Coursera Co-Founder Andrew Ng | publisher =Degree of Freedom | date = May 17, 2013| url =http://degreeoffreedom.org/interview-with-coursera-co-founder-andrew-ng/ | access-date =May 19, 2013 }} }}In 2011, Stanford launched a total of three massive open online courses (MOOCs) on machine learning (CS229a), [[database]]s, and AI, taught by Ng, [[Peter Norvig]], [[Sebastian Thrun]], and [[Jennifer Widom]].{{cite web|url=https://www.andrewng.org/portfolio/origins-of-the-modern-mooc-xmooc/|title=Origins of the Modern MOOC|last1=Ng|first1=Andrew|last2=Widom|first2=Jennifer}}{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/papers/mooc14-OriginsOfModernMOOC.pdf|title=Origins of the Modern MOOC (xMOOC)|last1=Ng|first1=Andrew|last2=Widom|first2=Jennifer}} This has led to the modern MOOC movement. Ng taught machine learning and Widom taught databases. The course on AI taught by Thrun led to the genesis of [[Udacity]]. [[Coursera]] was the 6th online education website that Ng built and arguably the most successful to date.{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-good-stories-from-the-early-days-of-Coursera|title=What are some good stories from the early days of Coursera? – Quora|website=quora.com|access-date=April 17, 2019}}{{blockquote|But we learned and learned and learned from the early prototypes, until in 2011 we managed to build something that really took off.}} The seeds of massive open online courses (MOOCs) go back a few years before the founding of Coursera in 2012. Two themes emphasized in the founding of modern MOOCs were ''scale'' and ''availability''. === Founding of Coursera === Ng started the [[Stanford Engineering Everywhere]] (SEE) program, which in 2008 published a number of Stanford courses online for free. Ng taught one of these courses, "Machine Learning", which includes his video lectures, along with the student materials used in the Stanford CS229 class. It offered a similar experience to [[MIT OpenCourseWare|MIT's Open Courseware]] except it aimed at providing a more "complete course" experience, equipped with lectures, course materials, problems and solutions, etc. The SEE videos were viewed by the millions and inspired Ng to develop and iterate new versions of online tech. Within Stanford, they include [[Daphne Koller]] with her "blended learning experiences" and co-designing a peer-grading system, John Mitchell (Courseware, a [[Learning management system|Learning Management System]]), [[Dan Boneh]] (using machine learning to sync videos, later teaching [[cryptography]] on Coursera), [[Bernd Girod]] (ClassX), and others. Outside Stanford both Ng and Thrun credit [[Sal Khan]] of [[Khan Academy]] as a huge source of inspiration. Ng was also inspired by [[LinkedIn Learning|lynda.com]] and the design of the forums of [[Stack Overflow]]. Widom, Ng, and others were ardent advocates of Khan-styled tablet recordings, and between 2009 and 2011, several hundred hours of lecture videos recorded by Stanford instructors were recorded and uploaded. Ng tested some of the original designs with a local high school to figure the best practices for recording lessons. In October 2011, the "applied" version of the Stanford class (CS229a) was hosted on ml-class.org and launched, with over 100,000 students registered for its first edition. The course featured quizzes and graded programming assignments and became one of the first and most successful massive open online courses (MOOCs) created by a Stanford professor.{{cite news |url=http://alumni.stanford.edu/get/page/magazine/article/?article_id=55991 | work=Stanford Magazine | author = Theresa Johnson | title = Stanford for All}} Two other courses on databases (db-class.org) and AI (ai-class.org) were launched. The ml-class and db-class ran on a platform developed by students, including Frank Chen, Jiquan Ngiam, Chuan-Yu Foo, and Yifan Mai. Word spread through social media and popular press. The three courses were 10 weeks long, and over 40,000 "Statements of Accomplishment" were awarded. Ng tells the following story on the early days of Coursera:{{blockquote|In 2011, I was working with four Stanford students. We were under tremendous pressure to build new features for the 100,000+ students that were already signed up. One of the students (Frank Chen) claims another one (Jiquan Ngiam) frequently stranded him in the Stanford building and refused to give him a ride back to his dorm until very late at night, so that he no choice but to stick around and keep working. I neither confirm nor deny this story.}} His work subsequently led to his founding of Coursera with Koller in 2012. As of 2019, the two most popular courses on the platform were taught and designed by Ng: "Machine Learning" (#1) and "Neural Networks and Deep Learning" (#2). === Post-Coursera work === In 2019, Ng launched a new course "AI for Everyone". This is a non-technical course designed to help people understand AI's impact on society and its benefits and costs for companies, as well as how they can navigate through this [[technological revolution]].{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/announcing-ai-for-everyone-a-new-course-from-deeplearning-ai-44b609c042f|title=Announcing "AI for Everyone": a new course from deeplearning.ai|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=November 14, 2018|website=Medium|access-date=December 14, 2018}} == Venture capital == Ng is the chair of the board for Woebot Labs, a psychological clinic that uses [[data science]] to provide [[cognitive behavioral therapy]]. It provides a therapy [[chatbot]] to help treat depression, among other things.{{cite web|url=https://woebot.io/|title=Woebot – Your charming robot friend who is here for you, 24/7|website=woebot.io|access-date=April 17, 2019}} He is also a member of the board of directors for [[drive.ai]], which uses AI for [[self-driving car]]s and was acquired by Apple in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrewyng/|title=Andrew Ng LinkedIn page}}{{cite web|url=https://www.drive.ai/|title=The self-driving car is here|website=drive.ai|access-date=April 17, 2019}} Through Landing AI, he also focuses on democratizing AI technology and lowering the barrier for entrance to businesses and developers. == Publications and awards == Ng is also the author or co-author of over 300, [[robotics]], and related fields.{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=mG4imMEAAAAJ&oi=sra|title=Andrew Ng – Google Scholar Citations|website=scholar.google.com|access-date=December 14, 2018}} His work in [[computer vision]] and [[deep learning]] has been frequently featured in press releases and reviews.[http://news.stanford.edu/news/2005/december7/robotsee-120705.html New algorithm improves robot vision] *1995. ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]''{{'s}} 40 under 40 {{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2013/09/19/fortunes-40-under-40-the-hottest-young-stars-in-business/|title=Fortune's 40 under 40 – The hottest young stars in business|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|access-date=February 19, 2018}} *2013. [[CNN]] 10: Thinkers{{Cite web|title=The CNN 10: Thinkers|url=http://www.cnn.com/interactive/2013/10/tech/cnn10-thinkers/|access-date=2020-12-26|website=CNN|language=en-US}} *2014. ''[[Fast Company]]''{{'s}} Most Creative People in Business{{Cite web|last=Staff|first=Fast Company|date=2014-01-29|title=Most Creative People In Business 1000: The Complete List|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3025456/most-creative-people-in-business-1000-the-complete-list|access-date=2020-12-26|website=[[Fast Company]]|language=en-US}} *2015. [[World Economic Forum's Young Global Leaders|World Economic Forum Young Global Leaders]]{{Cite web |date=September 2014 |title=Convening Innovators from the Science and Technology Communities |url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/AMNC14/WEF_AMNC14_ScienceTechnology_Brochure.pdf|url-status=live |publisher=[[World Economic Forum]]}} He has co-refereed hundreds of AI publications in journals like [[Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems|NeurIPS]]. He has also been the editor for the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR), Associate Editor for the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|IEEE]] Robotics and Automation Society Conference Editorial Board (ICRA), and much more. He has given invited talks at [[NASA]], [[Google]], [[Microsoft]], [[Lockheed Martin]], the [[Max Planck Society]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], [[University of Pennsylvania|UPenn]], [[Cornell University|Cornell]], [[MIT]], [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]], and dozens of other universities. Outside of the US, he has lectured in Spain, Germany, Israel, China, Korea, and Canada. He has also written for ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', ''[[HuffPost]]'', ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', ''[[Apple News]]'', and Quora Sessions' Twitter.{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/profile/Andrew-Ng|title=Andrew Ng – Quora|website=quora.com|access-date=April 17, 2019}} He also writes a weekly digital newsletter called ''The Batch''. == Books == He also wrote a book ''Machine Learning Yearning'', a practical guide for those interested in machine learning, which he distributed for free.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlyearning.org/|title=Machine Learning Yearning|year=2017}} In December 2018, he wrote a sequel called ''AI Transformation Playbook''.{{cite web|url=https://landing.ai/ai-transformation-playbook/|title=AI Transformation Playbook How to lead your company into the AI era|date=December 13, 2018|website=Landing AI|access-date=December 14, 2018}} Ng contributed one chapter to ''Architects of Intelligence: The Truth About AI from the People Building it'' (2018) by the American futurist [[Martin Ford (author)|Martin Ford]]. == Views on AI == Ng believes that AI technology will improve the lives of people, not that it is an anathema that will "enslave" the human race. Ng believes the potential benefits of AI outweigh the threats, which he believes are exaggerated.{{cite web|title=Is AI an existential threat to humanity? – Quora|url=https://www.quora.com/Is-AI-an-existential-threat-to-humanity|access-date=2019-04-17|website=quora.com}} He has stated that{{blockquote|Worrying about AI evil superintelligence today is like worrying about overpopulation on the planet Mars. We haven't even landed on the planet yet!}}A real threat is regarding the future of work: "Rather than being distracted by evil killer robots, the challenge to labour caused by these machines is a conversation that academia and industry and government should have."{{Cite news |first=Nick |last=Thieme |date=2017-08-01|title=Zuckerberg and Musk are arguing about the dangers of AI – they're both wrong|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/world/zuckerberg-and-musk-are-arguing-about-the-dangers-of-ai-theyre-both-wrong|access-date=2020-12-26|website=[[The Straits Times]]}} A particular goal of Ng's work is to "democratize" AI learning so that people can learn more about it and understand its benefits. Ng's stance on AI is shared by [[Mark Zuckerberg]], but opposed by [[Elon Musk]]. In 2017, Ng said he supported [[basic income]] to allow the unemployed to study AI so that they can re-enter the workforce. He has stated that he enjoyed [[Erik Brynjolfsson]] and [[Andrew McAfee|Andrew McAfee's]] "[[The Second Machine Age]]" which discusses issues such as AI displacement of jobs.{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/How-will-work-and-jobs-change-by-2035|title=How will work and jobs change by 2035?
